candidates.name: John Cornyn
candidates.summary: Four-term incumbent U.S. Senator, former Texas Attorney General and Texas Supreme Court Justice. The Senate's former second-ranking Republican (Majority Whip), now seeking an unprecedented fifth term while facing his toughest primary challenge yet.
candidates.background: Born in Houston (1952), grew up in San Antonio. B.A. in journalism from Trinity University (1973), J.D. from St. Mary's Law School (1977), LL.M. from University of Virginia (1995). Practiced law in San Antonio defending doctors and lawyers in malpractice suits. Elected Bexar County district judge in 1984, serving until 1990. Elected to the Texas Supreme Court in 1990. Elected Texas Attorney General in 1997 — the first Republican to hold the office since Reconstruction. Elected to the U.S. Senate in 2002 with 55% of the vote; re-elected in 2008, 2014, and 2020. Served as Senate Republican Whip (2013-2019), the second-highest ranking position in the Republican Conference. Currently chairs the Senate Subcommittee on Border Security and Immigration. Led passage of the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act (gun safety bill) in 2022 and the CHIPS and Science Act.
keyPositions: Border security — backed Trump's $46.6B border wall funding
Semiconductor manufacturing and CHIPS Act implementation
Tax reform — supported Trump tax cuts
99.2% voting record with President Trump
Law enforcement funding and support
Stop Dangerous Sanctuary Cities Act
endorsements: Former Gov. Rick Perry (Lone Star Freedom Project — spent ~$18M on his behalf)
Combined Law Enforcement Associations of Texas (CLEAT)
Former Texas DPS Director Steve McCraw
Former Fort Worth Mayor Betsy Price
pros: Most effective legislator in the race — real deliverables for Texas (CHIPS Act, border funding, Operation Lone Star reimbursements)
Strongest general election candidate — avoids Paxton's legal baggage liability
Massive spending advantage (~$59M+ in allied spending, $15M+ cash on hand)
Deep institutional relationships — former Whip with ability to deliver for Texas
Broad law enforcement support from border patrol to municipal police
cons: 24-year Washington career makes him vulnerable to 'career politician' attacks
Bipartisan gun safety bill is a major liability with the GOP base — opponents call him 'anti-gun'
Past support for DREAM Act, Ukraine aid, and willingness to compromise seen as insufficiently conservative
Trailing Paxton in recent polls despite vastly outspending him
candidates.fundraising: Dominant fundraiser: raised $7M+ in Q4 2025 alone (career high). $15M+ total cash on hand across campaign and joint committees ($5.9M in campaign account). Allied outside groups including Rick Perry's Lone Star Freedom Project have spent roughly $59M+. Three-quarters of all GOP-side spending supports Cornyn.
candidates.polling: 31% in latest UH poll (Jan 2026) — second place behind Paxton's 38%. RealClearPolitics average: 28%. Likely headed to a May runoff with Paxton.

candidates.name: Ken Paxton
candidates.summary: Three-term Texas Attorney General and conservative firebrand challenging the incumbent. Impeached by the Texas House in 2023 but acquitted by the Senate. Securities fraud charges were dismissed in 2025 after completing a pretrial diversion program. Currently leads primary polling.
candidates.background: Born in Minot, North Dakota (1962), grew up on military bases. B.A. in psychology and M.B.A. from Baylor University (1985, 1986), where he was student body president. J.D. from University of Virginia School of Law (1991). Worked as attorney at Strasburger & Price, then as in-house counsel at J.C. Penney, then ran his own law firm in McKinney for 14 years. Elected to the Texas House of Representatives in 2002 (District 70), serving 10 years. Elected to the Texas State Senate in 2012 (District 8). Elected Attorney General in 2014, re-elected in 2018 and 2022. As AG, led more than 4,000 employees in 38 divisions. Filed numerous high-profile lawsuits against the Biden and Obama administrations on immigration and border policy. Impeached by the Texas House in May 2023 on 20 articles including bribery, obstruction, and abuse of office; acquitted by the Texas Senate in September 2023 (16-14, short of the 21 needed to convict). Securities fraud charges (indicted 2015) were dismissed in June 2025 after completing a pretrial diversion agreement requiring $300,000 restitution, 200 hours of community service, and 15 hours of legal ethics training — without admitting wrongdoing.
keyPositions: Take a 'sledgehammer to the D.C. establishment'
Secure the border and deport undocumented immigrants
Champion Trump's legislative priorities and cut taxes
Protect Second Amendment rights
Election integrity — support voter ID nationwide
Defend the unborn and oppose transgender policies
pros: Highest name recognition and favorability among Republican primary voters
Proven record of aggressive litigation against federal overreach — won multiple landmark cases
Strong alignment with MAGA base and grassroots conservative movement
Leading in polls despite being vastly outspent — organic grassroots support
cons: Impeached by his own party's House — 121 Republican House members voted to impeach
Senior staff reported him to the FBI for bribery and abuse of office (whistleblower case)
Securities fraud charges required $300K restitution and community service to resolve
General election vulnerability — Democrats view him as the most beatable Republican nominee
candidates.fundraising: Raised $5.3M total (April-December 2025). Cash on hand: ~$3.7M. Outraised by Cornyn every quarter but competitive. Has relied more on grassroots small-dollar donations and earned media than paid advertising.
candidates.polling: 38% in latest UH poll (Jan 2026) — frontrunner. Emerson College poll (mid-Jan): 27% in tighter survey. RealClearPolitics average: 30%. Leads in most public polls.

candidates.name: Wesley Hunt
candidates.summary: Two-term U.S. Representative from Houston, West Point graduate, and decorated Apache helicopter combat pilot. Pitching himself as a younger, next-generation alternative who can bridge the gap between the GOP establishment and MAGA base.
candidates.background: Born in Houston (1981). Attended St. John's School in Houston. B.S. in leadership and management with mechanical engineering from the United States Military Academy at West Point (2004). Served 8 years in the U.S. Army as an Apache helicopter pilot, including one deployment to Iraq (55 combat air missions) and two deployments to Saudi Arabia as a Diplomatic Liaison Officer. After military service, earned an M.B.A., M.P.A., and M.I.L.R. from Cornell University. Elected to Congress in 2022 representing Texas's 38th Congressional District. Serves on the House Natural Resources and Judiciary Committees. Was the first person in Texas — and one of the first nationally — to endorse Donald Trump for president on November 15, 2022. Entered the Senate race on October 6, 2025.
keyPositions: Codify DOGE spending cuts into law
Secure the border — authored invasion declaration legislation
Protect American energy and Texas oil and gas industry
Strong Second Amendment supporter
Support military veterans and families
Next-generation leadership — 'Senate is not a retirement community'
endorsements: Allen West (former Florida congressman, Dallas County GOP Chair)
Allied super PAC spending $7.2M+ on ads
pros: Exceptional personal resume — West Point, combat veteran, triple Ivy League degrees
Youngest candidate at 44 — generational change argument
Military service and combat experience lend credibility on national security
Can potentially appeal to both MAGA activists and traditional Republicans
First in Texas to endorse Trump — early MAGA loyalty
cons: Distant third in polls at 17% — splits the anti-Paxton vote and may not make the runoff
Missed 92% of House votes in 2026 (44 of 48) while campaigning — drew bipartisan criticism
Only two terms in Congress — limited legislative track record
Previously supported Hillary Clinton in 2008 — used as attack line by opponents
candidates.fundraising: Raised ~$1.8M total across campaign and affiliated committees. Cash on hand: ~$3M (including transfers). Allied super PAC has spent $7.2M+ on ads. Significantly outspent by Cornyn and outraised by Paxton.
candidates.polling: 17% in latest UH poll (Jan 2026) — third place. Emerson College: 16%. RealClearPolitics average: 20%. Most likely scenario: does not make the runoff, with Cornyn and Paxton advancing to the May 26 runoff.

recommendation.reasoning: Most effective legislator in the race with real deliverables for Texas. If stopping Paxton matters to you, Cornyn is the only viable vehicle — Hunt splits the opposition vote at 17%. Cornyn's institutional relationships and fundraising dominance make him the strongest general election candidate.
recommendation.strategicNotes: A runoff between the top two is almost certain. Every opposition vote for Cornyn helps ensure he makes the runoff in the strongest position.
recommendation.caveats: 24-year career politician, which frustrates some voters. His bipartisan gun safety bill is a major liability with the base. But Paxton's impeachment and securities fraud history present serious concerns.

candidates.name: Chip Roy
candidates.summary: Four-term U.S. Representative (TX-21) and former First Assistant Attorney General under Ken Paxton. Federal prosecutor background with deep AG office experience. Frontrunner polling at 33% who has broken with both Trump and Paxton on principle.
candidates.background: B.S. in Commerce and M.S. in Information Systems from University of Virginia. J.D. from University of Texas School of Law (2003). Served as Special Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Texas. Worked for Gov. Rick Perry's presidential campaign. Chief of staff and top political strategist for Sen. Ted Cruz (2012-2015). Served as Ken Paxton's inaugural First Assistant Attorney General (2015-2016), overseeing 28,000+ active cases including voter ID, same-sex marriage, and the United States v. Texas immigration lawsuit (DAPA). Elected to U.S. Congress in 2018, serving four terms representing TX-21.
keyPositions: Border security and immigration enforcement
Challenge Plyler v. Doe to end public school mandate for undocumented children
Remove lenient district attorneys
Defend Texas from federal overreach regardless of party
Oppose Obergefell v. Hodges
Fight sanctuary cities through AG opinions
endorsements: U.S. Reps. Lauren Boebert, Michael Cloud, Byron Donalds, Ronny Jackson, Keith Self, Pete Sessions, Beth Van Duyne
Young Conservatives of Texas (dual endorsement with Middleton)
pros: Most direct AG office experience — served as First Assistant overseeing the entire agency
Federal prosecutor background in criminal cases
Constitutional conservative willing to challenge both parties on principle
Frontrunner with broadest coalition of support
Built the AG office's team including future federal judges and commissioners
cons: Called Trump's Jan. 6 conduct 'clearly impeachable' — liability with MAGA base
Voted to certify the 2020 election
History of blocking his own party's legislation over spending concerns drew 'obstructionist' label
Opponents claim Paxton fired him (Roy says they had 'differences of opinion')
candidates.fundraising: $4.5M raised (July-Dec 2025), with $2M transferred from congressional campaign. $4.2M cash on hand. 85% of donations under $100. Major donor: Amarillo billionaire Alex Fairly.
candidates.polling: 33% — frontrunner (UH Hobby School poll, Jan 2026). Other candidates trying to keep him below 50% to force runoff.

candidates.name: Mayes Middleton
candidates.summary: State Senator, oil and gas executive, and prolific GOP donor who has self-funded nearly $12M into the race. Brands himself 'MAGA Mayes' and runs on his record as one of Texas' most conservative legislators rather than courtroom experience.
candidates.background: B.S. in Finance from University of Texas at Austin. J.D. from University of Texas School of Law. President of Middleton Oil Company, an independent oil and gas company operating in South Texas and the Gulf Coast. Elected to Texas House (District 23) in 2018, serving two terms. Elected to Texas Senate (District 11, Galveston/Chambers counties) in 2022. Chairman of the Texas Freedom Caucus. Consistently ranked as one of the top 10 most conservative members of the Texas Legislature. Licensed attorney but has practiced law exclusively within his family's oil and gas company.
keyPositions: Deport all illegal immigrants and sue sanctuary cities
Ban transgender athletes from women's sports
Display Ten Commandments in public schools — rejects separation of church and state
Create standalone election integrity task force with law enforcement powers
Criminalize hormone therapy for minors
Aggressively enforce Trump's border security and deportation orders
endorsements: U.S. Reps. Brian Babin, Lance Gooden, Randy Weber
State Sens. Brent Hagenbuch, Adam Hinojosa
25+ state representatives including Briscoe Cain, Brian Harrison, Steve Toth, Ellen Troxclair, Carrie Isaac
Young Conservatives of Texas (dual endorsement with Roy)
pros: Massive financial resources — can self-fund indefinitely
Strongest conservative legislative record in the field
Deep network of state legislator endorsements
Has a law degree from UT Law
cons: Zero courtroom experience — never tried a case, filed a motion, or argued an appeal
All legal work confined to family oil company — opponents say 'literally no law experience'
Relying on self-funding ($11M+ of his own money) rather than broad donor base
Running on ideology rather than legal qualifications for the state's top lawyer
candidates.fundraising: $11.8M raised (July-Dec 2025), but over 90% self-funded. Spent $6M on ads and mailers. $5M cash on hand.
candidates.polling: 23% — second place (UH Hobby School poll, Jan 2026). Best positioned to force Roy into a runoff.

candidates.name: Joan Huffman
candidates.summary: Longtime state senator, former Harris County criminal prosecutor and district judge. The most legally experienced candidate in the field, running a 'law and order' campaign that contrasts with opponents' culture war focus, but trailing in polls, fundraising, and endorsements.
candidates.background: B.A. from Louisiana State University. J.D. from South Texas College of Law (earned while working full-time as a secretary in the Harris County DA's office). Served 14 years as a Harris County prosecutor, rising from misdemeanor court to Chief Felony Prosecutor, Special Crimes Gang Prosecutor, and Legal Counsel to the Organized Crime Narcotics Task Force. Served as judge of the 183rd Criminal District Court in Harris County, presiding over thousands of criminal cases including death penalty cases. Texas State Senator (District 17) since 2008. Chaired the Senate Finance Committee (lead budget writer), Senate State Affairs Committee, and Senate Redistricting Committee. Presided over the Ken Paxton impeachment trial in the Senate.
keyPositions: Law and order — enhance public safety through stronger law enforcement partnerships
Beef up AG office's criminal investigation and prosecution divisions
Rule of law — 'I'm going to be a law follower and a rule follower'
Build relationships with district attorneys statewide rather than threatening removal
Focus on competent governance over press conferences and political lawsuits
endorsements: State Sens. Robert Nichols, Donna Campbell
pros: Most courtroom experience of any candidate — 14 years as prosecutor, then district judge
Deep institutional knowledge of state government from 16+ years in the Senate
Endorsed by every major Texas newspaper
Endorsed by law enforcement organizations
Measured, experienced approach to the office
cons: Trailing badly in polls at 13% — may not be viable
Lowest fundraising in the field ($2.7M cash on hand)
Measured approach may not resonate with GOP primary voters seeking a fighter
Drew gerrymander criticism for her redistricting committee work
candidates.fundraising: $2.7M cash on hand. Raised over $500K and spent over $860K in the July-Dec 2025 period. Trails all three opponents in both new donations and cash on hand.
candidates.polling: 13% — third place (UH Hobby School poll, Jan 2026). Significantly behind Roy and Middleton.

candidates.name: Aaron Reitz
candidates.summary: Ken Paxton's chosen successor and former Deputy AG for Legal Strategy. Marine combat veteran and Federalist Society leader who vows to 'destroy the left.' Endorsed by Paxton but trailing in polls and fundraising.
candidates.background: Graduated magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Texas A&M University (B.S., 2009), where he was Regimental Commander of the Corps of Cadets. Served five years active duty in the U.S. Marine Corps, deploying to Helmand Province, Afghanistan with 2nd Battalion, 4th Marines. J.D. from University of Texas School of Law (2017), where he was President of the Texas Federalist Society and Editor in Chief of the Texas Review of Law & Politics. Began legal career at Bracewell LLP in Houston. Clerked for Justice Jimmy Blacklock on the Texas Supreme Court. Served as Deputy Attorney General for Legal Strategy under Ken Paxton, driving the Texas v. Biden docket and leading cases on border security, immigration, Big Tech, and election integrity. Served as Chief of Staff for Sen. Ted Cruz. Briefly served as Assistant Attorney General at the U.S. DOJ Office of Legal Policy (confirmed March 2025, resigned less than three months later to run for AG).
keyPositions: Continue Paxton's aggressive litigation agenda
Support mass deportations and partner with Trump administration
Crack down on 'big blue cities' — remove lenient DAs
Challenge Plyler v. Doe
Oppose 'Islamification of Texas'
Stop flow of abortion pills into Texas
endorsements: Texas AG Ken Paxton ('complete and total endorsement')
pros: Direct AG office experience as Deputy AG for Legal Strategy
Deep knowledge of the AG's active litigation docket
Marine combat veteran with strong service record
Strongest grassroots donor base — more individual donations than other candidates combined
cons: Lowest polling at 6% — not viable without dramatic shift
Resigned from DOJ post after less than 3 months, drawing criticism
Deleted ~4,000 tweets before confirmation hearings including controversial posts
Called Simone Biles a 'selfish, childish national embarrassment' — even Paxton called it 'very inappropriate'
Closely tied to Paxton, whose legal and ethical troubles are well-documented
candidates.fundraising: $3M cash on hand, all raised since June 2025 campaign launch. Claims more individual donations than other candidates combined. Top donors: Houston media exec Jonathan Knutz and Austin energy exec Matthew Calhoun (each over $100K).
candidates.polling: 6% — fourth place (UH Hobby School poll, Jan 2026). Would need dramatic movement to be viable.

recommendation.reasoning: Best combination of legal experience and principled conservatism. Actually served in the AG's office and resigned on principle. Federal prosecutor background gives him credibility for the role.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Roy needs 50% to avoid a runoff. Consolidating behind the frontrunner helps avoid a prolonged primary.

candidates.name: Kelly Hancock
candidates.summary: Acting Comptroller since July 2025, appointed after Glenn Hegar resigned. Former state senator with a decade on the Senate Finance Committee and five years on the Legislative Budget Board. Authored the state spending cap law.
candidates.background: Born December 2, 1963, in Fort Worth. BBA from Baylor University (1986). Co-founded Advanced Chemical Logistics, a chemical distribution company, in 2003. Served 13 years on the Birdville ISD school board. Elected to the Texas House (District 91) for three terms, then served 12 years in the Texas Senate (District 9, 2007-2025). Chaired the Senate Business and Commerce Committee. Served a decade on the Senate Finance Committee and five years on the Legislative Budget Board. Authored the law preventing state spending from growing faster than inflation plus population growth. Resigned from the Senate in June 2025 to become Chief Clerk of the Comptroller's office; became Acting Comptroller when Hegar departed July 1, 2025. Currently overseeing implementation of the Texas Education Freedom Accounts (school voucher program).
keyPositions: Fiscal discipline and state spending cap enforcement
School voucher implementation and oversight
Ending DEI in state contracting
Border security reimbursement for sheriffs
Keeping taxes low while growing the economy
Barring schools with foreign adversary ties from voucher program
endorsements: Combined Law Enforcement Associations of Texas (CLEAT)
Associated Builders and Contractors Texas PAC
pros: Most relevant fiscal experience of any candidate — decade on Senate Finance and five years on Legislative Budget Board
Currently doing the job as Acting Comptroller, providing real-world operational knowledge
Authored the state spending cap law, directly relevant to the Comptroller's revenue estimation role
Broad institutional support from law enforcement, business, and agriculture groups
Clean ethical record with no known conflicts of interest
cons: Insider appointment — resigned from Senate to take a staff job, then became acting comptroller when Hegar left, which critics call a backroom deal
Only polling at ~13%, suggesting low name recognition and viability concerns
58% of polled Republicans said they did not know enough about him to have an opinion
Governor endorsement may carry less weight than in prior cycles
candidates.fundraising: Raised $2.2M as of late 2025, with $6M cash on hand. Strong institutional donor base from business and industry PACs. Outraised by both Huffines and Craddick in direct fundraising but maintains competitive cash reserves.
candidates.polling: 13% — third place (UH Hobby School poll, Feb 2026). 58% of Republicans polled said they didn't know enough about him to have an opinion.

candidates.name: Don Huffines
candidates.summary: Former state senator and Dallas real estate developer running on a 'DOGE Texas' government efficiency platform. Best-funded candidate at over $15M (mostly self-funded). Polling frontrunner at 33%. Lost the 2022 governor's primary to Abbott and lost his Senate seat in 2018.
candidates.background: Born April 26, 1958, in Dallas. Fifth-generation Texan. BBA in Finance from the University of Texas at Austin. Grew up in the family automotive business (Huffines Motor Company, 90+ year legacy). Co-founded Huffines Communities, a Dallas-Fort Worth real estate development company, with twin brother Phillip in 1985. Served in the Texas Senate (District 16, 2015-2019) as a Tea Party Republican. Rated the fourth-most conservative member of the 2017 Texas Senate by Rice University's Baker Institute. Lost re-election in 2018 to Democrat Nathan Johnson — the first Democrat to win that district in 30+ years. Ran for governor in 2022, finishing third with 12% against Abbott. Announced comptroller bid March 7, 2025. As a senator, declined all salary, pension, healthcare, and per diem.
keyPositions: DOGE Texas — create a state Department of Government Efficiency to expose waste, fraud, and abuse
Slash property taxes using savings from government efficiency audits
Eliminate DEI programs in government and schools
No taxpayer-funded benefits for undocumented immigrants
End corporate welfare and green energy subsidies
Implement gold and silver-backed currency through the Texas Bullion Depository
endorsements: Over two-thirds of the State Republican Executive Committee
pros: Best-funded campaign in the race with $15M+ and massive advertising advantage
Strong MAGA brand alignment with 'DOGE Texas' platform that resonates with primary voters
Highest name recognition among Republican primary voters, polling at 33%
Pledges to take no salary, pension, or benefits — signals personal financial independence
Deep roster of high-profile national conservative endorsements including Ted Cruz
cons: $10M+ is self-funded via personal loans, raising questions about using the office to benefit his real estate interests
Lost two consecutive races — Senate seat in 2018 and governor's race in 2022 with only 12%
Family purchased Jeffrey Epstein's former Zorro Ranch in New Mexico at public auction, now under renewed investigation by NM attorney general
Some policy proposals (gold-backed currency, state DOGE) are aspirational but lack clear implementation path through the Comptroller's actual statutory powers
candidates.fundraising: Over $15M raised total. $10M in personal loans. $3M donation from brother. $1M+ from outside donors. $11.8M cash on hand as of Dec 2025. Heaviest spending in the race on advertising.
candidates.polling: 33% — frontrunner (UH Hobby School poll, Feb 2026). Leads Craddick by 12 points and Hancock by 20 points. 29% of voters remain undecided.

candidates.name: Christi Craddick
candidates.summary: Three-term Texas Railroad Commissioner since 2012 and oil and gas attorney. Only candidate to have won three statewide elections. Daughter of former TX House Speaker Tom Craddick. Running on fiscal accountability and agency modernization.
candidates.background: Born July 1, 1970, in Midland, Texas. Daughter of State Rep. Tom Craddick, who served as Speaker of the Texas House (2003-2009) and is the longest-serving current Texas state legislator. Plan II honors graduate and J.D. from the University of Texas at Austin. Member of the Texas State Bar. Practiced as an oil and gas attorney specializing in tax, water, electric deregulation, and environmental policy. Served nine years as an adviser to her father during his speakership. President of a grassroots advocacy firm focused on coalition building and issue strategy. Elected to the Texas Railroad Commission in 2012; served as Commission Chairman beginning August 2014. Re-elected in 2018 and 2024 for a third term. Announced comptroller campaign March 2025.
keyPositions: Full audit of every state dollar spent to catch waste
Create a Local Government Efficiency Task Force
Modernize outdated Comptroller technology systems
Support school voucher program with responsible oversight
Partner with legislators on accurate revenue forecasts
Conservative fiscal leadership with limited, transparent government
endorsements: G. Brint Ryan (CEO of Ryan LLC, $250K personal donation)
Ray L. Hunt and Woody Hunt (Hunt family)
Various oil and gas industry leaders and West Texas business figures
pros: 12+ years managing a statewide regulatory agency with a large budget and staff — proven executive experience
Only candidate who has won three statewide elections, demonstrating broad voter appeal
Campaign emphasis on auditing and technology modernization addresses real Comptroller operational needs
Strong fundraising from business community without relying on self-funding
cons: Holds $20M+ in oil and gas mineral lease interests while serving as energy regulator — documented conflicts of interest including casting a deciding vote favoring a company she held stock in
Defended fossil fuel industry and resisted mandatory weatherization after the 2021 winter storm that killed hundreds of Texans
Father's political dynasty raises dynasty/nepotism concerns
Railroad Commission experience, while executive, is not directly fiscal or financial in nature
candidates.fundraising: $3.2M raised as of Sept 2025. Largest donor: Brint Ryan and 71 employees contributed ~$1M in an 8-day period. Additional $100K+ donations from oil industry figures. Strong industry donor base but no significant self-funding.
candidates.polling: 21% — second place (UH Hobby School poll, Feb 2026). Trails Huffines by 12 points but leads Hancock by 8 points.

candidates.name: Michael Berlanga
candidates.summary: Lesser-known candidate in the Comptroller race.
cons: Low name recognition
Minimal campaign infrastructure

recommendation.reasoning: Most relevant fiscal experience — 10 years on Senate Finance, authored the spending cap, currently doing the job. Clean record with no conflicts of interest.
recommendation.strategicNotes: At only 13%, Hancock may not be viable. If stopping Huffines is the priority, Craddick at 21% is the strategic alternative.
recommendation.caveats: Insider appointment feels like backroom dealing. If strategic viability matters more, consider Craddick.

candidates.name: Nate Sheets
candidates.summary: Fifth-generation Texan entrepreneur who built Nature Nate's Honey from a single backyard beehive into the #1 branded honey company in America. Navy veteran and 10,000-acre ranch operator. Governor Abbott endorsed him over the incumbent — a rare and significant rebuke of a fellow Republican.
candidates.background: Born and raised in the Texas Hill Country. Served in the U.S. Naval Reserve from 1988 to 1994. Graduated from Texas State University with a BBA in Marketing. Founded North Dallas Honey Company, later rebranded as Nature Nate's, which became the #1 branded honey in America and a pioneer in food purity testing. Sold the company in 2021 and resigned as CEO in 2024 to run for Agriculture Commissioner. Currently owns and operates Honey Rock Ranch, a 10,000-acre property in West Texas (formerly part of the historic 6666's Ranch), where he manages wildlife, runs a cow/calf operation, trains cutting horses, and experiments with regenerative ranching practices. First-time political candidate.
keyPositions: DOGE the agency — audit TDA to cut unnecessary taxes, fees, and regulations
MAHA the school lunch program — prioritize Texas-grown produce and meat over ultra-processed foods
Stop foreign ownership of Texas farmland
Bring new jobs to rural Texas through agricultural processing and refining
Protect bee populations and promote food purity standards
Support Texas farmers in raising and selling clean, healthy food
endorsements: Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (28,000+ members)
Texas Cattle Feeders Association BEEF PAC
12+ members of the State Republican Executive Committee
pros: Built a nationally dominant agriculture business from scratch — deep firsthand understanding of Texas food production
Massive endorsement coalition spanning ag industry groups, elected officials, and conservative organizations
Leading fundraiser in the race — $506K raised with $373K cash on hand
Navy veteran with discipline and leadership background
Governor endorsed him over the three-term incumbent — extraordinary signal
cons: No government or political experience — first-time candidate
Low name recognition: 65% of polled voters don't know enough about him to have an opinion
Trails badly in early polling despite major advantages in money and endorsements
Significant campaign contributions from associates, business partners, and family ($410K+) raise self-funding questions
candidates.fundraising: Strong — $506,224 raised, $373,235 cash on hand. Three times Miller's fundraising since the start of 2025. Over $410,000 from associates, business partners, and family.
candidates.polling: Trailing — 18% vs. Miller's 49% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 20-31, 2026). 65% of voters say they don't know enough about him.

candidates.name: Sid Miller
candidates.summary: Three-term incumbent first elected in 2014, formerly a 12-year state representative. Trump endorsed him twice (2018, 2022). Plagued by ethics scandals including a convicted aide he then hired as chief of staff, and allegations of misusing public funds for personal travel.
candidates.background: Born in De Leon, Comanche County, in 1955. Associate's degree from Cisco Junior College; B.S. in Vocational Agriculture Education from Tarleton State University (1978). Former ag teacher and school board member. Served in the Texas House of Representatives for District 59 from 2001 to 2013 (lost primary runoff in 2012). Elected 12th Texas Commissioner of Agriculture in 2014; re-elected 2018 and 2022. Farmer, rancher, and businessman who breeds and trains American Quarter Horses. Championship rodeo cowboy with multiple AQHA world championship titles. Hosts a national agriculture show on RFD-TV.
keyPositions: America First beef policy — heifer retention tax credit and stronger country-of-origin labeling
Rebuild U.S. cattle herd and domestic processing capacity
Increase Texas-grown food in school lunch programs
Oppose increased Argentine beef imports
Hemp regulation and THC policy adjustments
Fight childhood obesity
endorsements: Former President Trump (endorsed 2018, 2022 — no 2026 endorsement yet)
10 members of the U.S. House of Representatives
pros: 11 years of experience running TDA — deep institutional knowledge
Strong name recognition among Republican primary voters (only 38% say they don't know him)
Leading in early polling despite being outspent and out-endorsed
Long record of advocacy on beef, trade, and ag policy at state and national level
cons: Fined by Texas Ethics Commission for using public funds for personal travel (including the 'Jesus shot' trip)

Longtime political consultant Todd Smith pleaded guilty to felony commercial bribery for selling hemp licenses — Miller then hired Smith as TDA chief of staff, the agency's second-highest-paid employee
Former allies told Texas Rangers that Miller asked them to dispose of marijuana products because he feared DEA inspection
Hired controversial figures including Carter Page; frequently posts misleading information on social media
candidates.fundraising: Weak — roughly $291,000 raised, significantly trailing Sheets. Being outraised approximately 3-to-1 since start of 2025.
candidates.polling: Leading — 49% vs. Sheets' 18% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 20-31, 2026). 34% undecided. Incumbency advantage in name recognition offsets money and endorsement deficits.

recommendation.reasoning: Entrepreneur vs. scandal-plagued incumbent. Governor Abbott himself broke ranks to endorse Sheets — that's how problematic Miller's tenure has been. Sheets would refocus the office on actual agriculture.
recommendation.strategicNotes: Miller leads in early polling on name recognition alone, but 34% of voters are undecided. The endorsement and fundraising advantages Sheets holds could close the gap as the primary approaches.
recommendation.caveats: Sheets has zero government experience and low name recognition. Miller, despite his scandals, has genuine policy accomplishments on beef and trade issues.

candidates.name: Greg Abbott
candidates.summary: Three-term incumbent seeking an unprecedented fourth term with a staggering $106M war chest. Faces 10 minor Republican primary challengers but none pose a credible threat. Named one of TIME's 100 Most Influential People in 2024.
candidates.background: Governor since 2015, making him the longest-serving incumbent governor in the United States. Former Texas Attorney General (2002-2015) — the longest-serving AG in state history. Appointed to the Texas Supreme Court by Gov. George W. Bush in 1996. Previously served as a judge on the 129th District Court in Houston (1993-1995) and practiced law privately (1984-1992). BBA from University of Texas at Austin; JD from Vanderbilt University. First Texas governor to use a wheelchair, following a 1984 accident when a tree fell on him while jogging. Successfully argued before the U.S. Supreme Court in Van Orden v. Perry (2005).
keyPositions: Border security (Operation Lone Star, $11B federal reimbursement request)
School choice ($1B voucher program signed into law May 2025)
Property tax relief ($18B in cuts, homestead exemption increases)
$20B water infrastructure investment
Ban on foreign adversary land purchases
Texas Cyber Command establishment
endorsements: Broad coalition of Texas agricultural and industry leaders
pros: $106M war chest — largest gubernatorial campaign fund in Texas history
Longest-serving incumbent governor in the U.S., with deep institutional knowledge
Presided over Texas becoming the #1 state for business every year of his tenure
Successfully pushed through nearly all 2025 legislative priorities including school vouchers, property tax relief, and water infrastructure
Strong relationship with Trump administration on border security
cons: 2021 winter storm grid failure killed over 200 Texans under his watch
Contradictory COVID-19 pandemic response drew criticism from both sides
Truck inspection policy at the Mexico border caused $4B+ in losses before being reversed
Some conservatives feel he is not aggressive enough on far-right priorities
candidates.fundraising: $106M cash on hand. Raised $22.7M from July-December 2025 alone with 48,000+ contributions from every county in Texas. Dwarfs all primary and general election opponents combined.
candidates.polling: No credible Republican primary challenger. Leads Democrat Gina Hinojosa 49%-42% in general election polling (UH Hobby School, Jan 2026). Emerson College poll shows 50%-42% lead.

candidates.name: Dan Patrick
candidates.summary: Three-term incumbent seeking a fourth term as Texas Lieutenant Governor and President of the Texas Senate. Endorsed by President Trump. Widely considered the most powerful Lt. Governor in Texas history, having passed all 40 of his stated legislative priorities in the 2025 session.
candidates.background: Lieutenant Governor since 2015. Served three terms in the Texas Senate (2007-2015) before defeating incumbent David Dewhurst in the 2014 Republican primary. Born in Baltimore, Maryland, as Dan Goeb; first in his family to graduate college. BA in English from University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Over 40 years in media as a TV anchor, conservative talk radio host, and station owner — put a then-unknown Rush Limbaugh on the air in Houston in 1988. Owned a chain of sports bars that went bankrupt before rebuilding his career in conservative talk radio. Hosted 'Dan Patrick & Friends' on KSEV 700 AM (Houston) and 1160 AM (Dallas). As Lt. Governor, presides over the Texas Senate and controls the Senate agenda, committee assignments, and floor calendar.
keyPositions: Property tax relief (delivered $18B in cuts, pushing for additional $40K homestead exemption increase)
School choice/vouchers (championed SB 2 education savings accounts, signed May 2025)
Border security (expanded state spending to $800M+)
Preventing Sharia law in Texas
Electric grid supply chain security against hostile foreign entities
Preventing fraud in health and human services programs
endorsements: President Donald Trump ('complete and total endorsement')
Served as Texas Chair for Trump's presidential campaigns in 2016, 2020, and 2024
pros: Most effective Lt. Governor in Texas history — passed all 40 priority bills in 2025 session
Delivered the largest property tax cut in Texas history ($18B), cutting school property taxes 41% for the average homeowner
$38M war chest — dwarfs all primary and general election opponents
Unmatched control over the Texas Senate agenda and committee assignments
Trump endorsement provides ironclad MAGA credentials
cons: Polarizing figure who has been criticized for overreach into House affairs, breaking the unwritten rule against interfering in the other chamber
Controversy over 'preventing Sharia law' priority, which critics call fearmongering since Sharia has no legal authority in the U.S.
Offered $1M bounty for voter fraud evidence after 2020 election; critics saw it as undermining election confidence
Pledged $1M to expand Turning Point USA across Texas, blurring lines between official duties and partisan activism
candidates.fundraising: $38M cash on hand as of mid-2025. Raised $5M in a single reporting period and $3.5M in Q4 2025. Second-highest recorded cash-on-hand balance of any state officeholder in Texas history. Democratic opponents have under $160K combined.
candidates.polling: No credible Republican primary challenger (three minor opponents: Perla Hopkins, Timothy Mabry, Esala Wueschner). Leads Democrat Vikki Goodwin 46%-41% in general election polling (UH Hobby School, Jan 2026).

candidates.name: Jim Wright
candidates.summary: Incumbent Railroad Commissioner since 2021, seeking re-election. Fifth-generation Texas rancher and oilfield entrepreneur who started in the energy sector at age 19. Leads a crowded five-candidate Republican primary but may face a runoff.
candidates.background: Railroad Commissioner since January 2021. Fifth-generation south Texas rancher from Orange Grove. Started working in the energy sector at age 19, digging ditches and hauling pipe. Built a group of environmental management companies servicing the energy industry, including DeWitt Recyclable Products, LLC (founded 2011, sold 2014). Professional Rodeo Cowboy Association member who competed in bull riding for over two decades. Education listed as Calallen High School; no college degree on public record. Founded and served as president of oilfield waste management companies. Emphasizes commonsense regulation, environmental responsibility, and innovation in energy policy.
keyPositions: Protect Texas energy through strong oil and gas production
Fair and consistent regulation — cut red tape and speed up permitting for pipelines and LNG terminals
Reduce flaring through better natural gas infrastructure and new market development
Proactive water and carbon management policy
Protect land, water, and people of Texas
Support emerging energy technologies including geothermal and hydrogen
pros: Deep hands-on energy industry experience spanning decades
Strong endorsement coalition from the governor, industry PACs, and conservative organizations
Incumbent with institutional knowledge of Railroad Commission operations
Best-funded candidate in the race ($912K total contributions, $447K cash on hand)
Pragmatic approach to emerging energy technologies like geothermal and hydrogen
cons: Continues to serve as president of an oilfield waste company and holds stock in others — direct conflict of interest as regulator
Founded DeWitt Recyclable Products, which after being sold was renamed Eagleford Recycling and had its permit canceled due to groundwater contamination concerns
Reached a settlement with the Railroad Commission over compliance issues prior to joining the commission
No college degree in a technical regulatory role
candidates.fundraising: $912,451 in total contributions, $446,666 cash on hand (as of Jan 2026). Top donors include oil and gas companies and industry PACs. Best-funded candidate in the five-person Republican primary.
candidates.polling: 21% — leading by 1 point over Jim Matlock (20%) in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 2026). Katherine Culbert at 8%, Bo French at 6%, Hawk Dunlap at 4%. 41% undecided. Runoff highly likely as no candidate is near 50%.

candidates.name: Katherine Culbert
candidates.summary: Houston-based process safety engineer with 20+ years in oil and gas. Formerly the 2024 Democratic nominee for Railroad Commissioner (lost to Christi Craddick by 16.6 points). Switched to the Republican primary for 2026, sparking controversy over the party change.
candidates.background: Licensed Chemical Engineer with over 20 years in process safety engineering for oil and gas and chemical companies. Worked across upstream, midstream, and downstream operations. BS in Paper Science & Engineering from SUNY College of Environmental Science & Forestry at Syracuse (1997). MBA from University at Albany. MS in Law with Regulatory and Compliance concentration from Northwestern University Pritzker School of Law (2020). Ran as the 2024 Democratic nominee for Railroad Commissioner, defeating Bill Burch in the Democratic primary before losing the general election to Republican Christi Craddick 58%-42%. Filed to run as a Republican in the 2026 primary, drawing criticism for switching parties after raising money through Democratic platforms including ActBlue.
keyPositions: Affordability — ensure Texans have access to a reliable and cost-conscious energy system
Adaptability — prepare Texas for a rapidly changing energy landscape through modernization
Accountability — require greater transparency in the agency's regulatory processes
Stronger enforcement of safety and environmental regulations
Ensure natural gas facilities prepare for extreme weather to prevent grid failures
Properly plug orphaned wells
pros: Deepest technical expertise of any candidate — licensed Chemical Engineer with 20 years in process safety
Three relevant degrees including a regulatory compliance law degree
Hands-on experience working with multiple regulatory agencies in a regulated industry
Only candidate with both industry AND regulatory/compliance expertise
cons: Ran as the Democratic nominee just 14 months ago — party switch raises credibility questions with Republican voters
Controversy over raising money through Democratic platforms (ActBlue) before filing as Republican
No endorsements from major Republican officials or organizations
Polling at only 8% with very low name recognition among Republican primary voters
candidates.fundraising: $279,695 cash on hand. Top donor: Miles Boldrick (Statewide Minerals Company) at $25,000. Significantly behind Wright in total fundraising.
candidates.polling: 8% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 2026). Trails Wright (21%) and Matlock (20%) significantly. 41% of voters undecided.

candidates.name: James "Jim" Matlock
candidates.summary: Sixth-generation Texan, disabled U.S. Marine Corps veteran, and oil and gas technical consultant from Nacogdoches with 18 years of field experience. Previously ran for Railroad Commissioner in 2024, finishing second with 26.6% of the vote. Polling tied for first at 20%.
candidates.background: Born in Fort Worth, adopted at birth, grew up in East Texas. Served in the U.S. Marine Corps Security Forces Company (anti-terrorist unit), completed service in 1995. Began oil and gas career in 2005 with 18 years spanning title work, truck supervision, small business ownership, consulting, and environmental remediation. Chaplain for the VFW and Texas State Guard. Operates Clean Act Remediation and Environmental Solutions of Texas.
keyPositions: Reduce oilfield waste — 'Don't tell me there's an energy crisis when I am still seeing waste'
Recycle produced water for fracking operations and irrigation-quality agricultural water
Capture flare gas through permitting reforms
Address orphaned and abandoned wells lacking oversight
Block foreign threats to Texas energy — prevent Chinese entities and firms like BlackRock from controlling Texas oil and gas
Protect independent producers and mineral rights holders against large corporate interests
pros: Extensive hands-on field experience (18 years) in oil and gas — a practitioner, not a lawyer or career politician
Strong 2024 primary performance (26.6% against an incumbent) demonstrates significant grassroots voter appeal
Polling tied for first at 20% despite minimal fundraising — authentic populist support
Military service (USMC anti-terrorist unit) and veteran advocacy
cons: Very limited fundraising ($6,566 in 2024 cycle) with no major donor base
No endorsements from major Republican officials, industry PACs, or organizations
Has not responded to media questionnaires from Ballotpedia, Community Impact, or San Antonio Report
No college degree publicly listed
candidates.fundraising: Minimal — $6,566 raised in 2024 cycle. Running a grassroots campaign without major donor support.
candidates.polling: 20% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 2026), tied for first with incumbent Wright (21%). 41% undecided.

candidates.name: Bo French
candidates.summary: Former Chairman of the Tarrant County Republican Party, energy investor, rancher, and self-described MAGA conservative from Fort Worth. Grew up in Midland in an oil family. Has the second-highest campaign war chest in the race but has generated controversy over inflammatory social media posts.
candidates.background: Born in Fort Worth, grew up in Midland in an oil industry family (father was a wildcatter). Attended New Mexico Military Institute. B.A. in History from TCU (1993). Career as an energy trader, investor, rancher, and security company owner. Served as Chairman of the Tarrant County Republican Party before resigning in November 2025 to run. Previously ran twice for Texas House District 99, losing both times.
keyPositions: Modernize permitting — streamline Railroad Commission regulatory processes
Eliminate DEI from the Railroad Commission
Block foreign influence — prevent CCP and hostile foreign entities from controlling Texas energy
Pro-Israel energy partnerships
pros: Strong fundraising (~$280K cash on hand) with notable oil industry donors
Deep Republican Party organizational experience as former Tarrant County GOP Chair
Grew up in Permian Basin oil culture with decades of energy sector experience
cons: Major controversy: posted a poll asking whether Jews or Muslims were 'the bigger threat to America,' leading Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick and Sen. John Cornyn to demand his resignation as Tarrant County GOP Chair
Campaign messaging largely disconnected from the Railroad Commission's actual regulatory mandate
Repeatedly used slurs against political opponents on social media
Two prior failed campaigns for Texas House (0-for-2)
candidates.fundraising: $279,695 cash on hand. Second only to incumbent Wright.
candidates.polling: 6% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 2026). Significantly trails Wright (21%) and Matlock (20%).

candidates.name: Hawk Dunlap
candidates.summary: International oil well control firefighter and blowout recovery expert from Longview with 35 years of oilfield experience spanning 103 countries. The most technically hands-on candidate on well safety issues. Previously ran as the Libertarian nominee in 2024 (2.6% in general).
candidates.background: Longview native. B.A. in Applied Arts and Sciences from Stephen F. Austin State University. 35-year career spanning drilling, workover operations, well control, blowout recovery, and risk management in onshore and offshore settings across 103 countries. Spent the last four years at Antina Ranch in West Texas personally addressing environmental damage from ~100 decades-old oil wells formerly operated by Chevron. Over 150,000 social media followers. Ran as Libertarian nominee in 2024 (285,544 votes / 2.6%).
keyPositions: Address orphaned/abandoned wells — top priority; proposes shared-cost model where all companies that ever operated a well share plugging costs
10-cent-per-barrel tariff on commercially injected oilfield wastewater (~$21M/week for well-plugging)
Require $60,000 plugging bonds per well from producers
Rename agency to 'Texas Energy Commission' to reflect actual mission
Deploy AI to project plugging costs and prioritize high-risk wells near schools and homes
Recycle produced water instead of underground injection disposal
pros: Unmatched field expertise in well control and blowout recovery — most technically qualified on well safety
35 years of global oilfield experience across 103 countries
Most detailed regulatory platform in the race with concrete, actionable proposals
Strong social media presence (150K+ followers) educating the public
cons: Very low polling (4%) and minimal fundraising ($32,668 cash on hand)
Switched from Libertarian (2024) to Republican (2026) — may raise credibility questions
New per-barrel taxes and higher bonding requirements may alienate pro-industry Republican voters
No endorsements from major Republican officials or industry PACs
candidates.fundraising: $32,668 cash on hand. Significantly behind all other candidates.
candidates.polling: 4% in UH Hobby School poll (Jan 2026). Trails all other candidates.

recommendation.reasoning: Incumbent with deep industry experience, strong endorsement coalition including the governor, and the most campaign resources. Despite conflict-of-interest concerns, he has governed pragmatically and embraced emerging energy technologies.
recommendation.strategicNotes: A runoff is highly likely with 41% undecided and five candidates splitting the vote. Culbert has the strongest technical qualifications but her recent party switch and 8% polling make her unviable in the Republican primary.
recommendation.caveats: Wright's ongoing business interests in the industry he regulates are a legitimate concern. Culbert's technical expertise would arguably serve the office well, but her party switch undermines her credibility with Republican voters.

candidates.name: Ge'Nell Gary
candidates.summary: Former Mayor and City Councilwoman of Albany, CA who relocated to Texas. Human resources professional and Austin Resource Management Commissioner now running as a Republican in the D+26 district.
candidates.background: Born in Wharton, TX. BA from Colorado Christian University, graduate degree from Regis University (2012). Career in human resources and liability program management. Moved to Albany, CA in 2018, served on the Library Board and Social and Economic Justice Commission, elected to Albany City Council in 2020, and served as Mayor. Participated in Emerge California (a Democratic women's candidate training program). Returned to Texas and appointed to Austin Resource Management Commission in March 2023 and Joint Sustainability Committee. Now identifies as Republican.
keyPositions: Community safety
Supporting families
Responsible energy and sustainability
Strengthening local neighborhoods
Faith-based conservative values
pros: Actual elected experience as Mayor and City Councilwoman
Government commission experience in Austin
Human resources and management background
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November
Previously trained through Emerge California, a Democratic candidate program — party switch may concern primary voters
Limited Texas-level political profile
candidates.fundraising: Minimal — no significant FEC filings found
candidates.polling: No polling available for this race

candidates.name: Lauren B. Pena
candidates.summary: Public-interest advocate, government-reform strategist, and human trafficking survivor whose decade of lived experience drives her mission to fight corruption and protect individual rights. Mother of four running on a Faith, Family, and Freedom platform.
candidates.background: Born in Harrisonburg, VA. Paralegal Certification from University of Texas (2023), BA in Political Science from Southern New Hampshire University (2024). Survived human trafficking for ten years. Has drafted and testified on legislation related to human trafficking, gun rights, redistricting, bail reform, medical freedom, and government accountability. Affiliated with the Austin Public Safety Commission, Austin Community Police Review Commission, and Travis County Republican Party. Previously ran for TX-35 in 2024.
keyPositions: Welfare reform that empowers families
Community policing and public safety
Federal spending accountability
Strong borders and responsible immigration
Sex Offender Deterrence Act (SODA)
Medical freedom and constitutional rights
pros: Powerful personal story as trafficking survivor brings unique policy perspective
Active civic engagement on multiple Austin commissions
Extensive legislative testimony experience on multiple issues
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November
Very recently completed BA degree (2024)
No elected office experience
Limited fundraising capacity
candidates.fundraising: FEC-registered (ID: H6TX35038) — minimal totals reported
candidates.polling: No polling available for this race

candidates.name: Janet Malzahn
candidates.summary: Texas attorney of 30+ years, UT Law graduate, former prosecutor and constitutional law professor. Now runs an AI implementation firm for the legal community and wants to make Austin a leader in ethical AI innovation.
candidates.background: Grew up in Canyon, TX. BA from Texas Tech, JD from University of Texas School of Law. Licensed attorney in Texas for 30+ years. Served as Assistant City Attorney in Dallas and as a prosecutor. Taught constitutional law. As Director of the National Institute for Child Support Enforcement, reformed Texas child support into a state profit center and cleared family court backlogs. Spent 20 years as an organizational development specialist and federal consultant, bringing Fortune 50 companies and federal agencies into compliance. Currently owns an AI implementation firm for the legal community (powered by Clio cloud consulting and vLex). Hosts a Constitutional podcast.
keyPositions: Make Austin #1 in ethical AI innovation and regulation
Lower housing costs and eliminate rising property taxes
Lower healthcare costs by removing federal regulations
School choice, vouchers, and parental rights (marches with Moms for Liberty)
Constitutional originalism and rule of law
Support for law enforcement
pros: Most professionally accomplished candidate in the race — 30+ years of legal practice
Deep policy expertise spanning child support enforcement, federal consulting, and AI
Constitutional law teaching background directly relevant to legislative work
Concrete Austin-focused economic vision around AI
cons: D+26 district — Republican nominee will lose in November
No prior elected office experience
AI business focus may feel niche to some voters
candidates.fundraising: Minimal — no significant FEC totals reported
candidates.polling: No polling available for this race

recommendation.reasoning: In a symbolic race (D+26 district), this vote is about expression rather than outcome. The Republican nominee will not win in November.
recommendation.strategicNotes: The real action in CD-37 is in the Democratic primary.
recommendation.caveats: Gary has elected experience but switched from Democrat; Pena has a compelling personal story but thin credentials; Malzahn has the deepest professional background. All three face the same D+26 reality.

candidates.name: Chris Gober
candidates.summary: Austin-based GOP election law attorney and former chief lawyer of Elon Musk's America PAC. Trump-endorsed frontrunner who has raised over $1M — more than 4x any rival. Harvard Law graduate with deep Republican establishment ties.
candidates.background: Degrees from Texas A&M and Harvard Law School. Served in national security and border security roles at the U.S. Department of Justice. Top lawyer for the Republican Party of Texas. Represented Sen. Ted Cruz in a campaign finance case that reached the U.S. Supreme Court in 2022. In 2024, served as director and chief lawyer of America PAC, founded by Elon Musk. Founded Lex Politica, a conservative law firm, building it from $10K in savings to 50+ employees across 17 states.
keyPositions: America First agenda
Election integrity
Promoting American technology investment
Border security
Conservative governance
Congressional term limits
pros: Overwhelming endorsement advantage — Trump, Abbott, Cruz, Johnson
Dominant fundraiser at $1.05M+, 4x any rival
Harvard Law + DOJ national security experience
Built a successful law firm from scratch
cons: Close ties to Elon Musk may be polarizing
No elected office experience
Establishment lane — some primary voters prefer outsiders
Crowded field still makes runoff likely
candidates.fundraising: $1.05M+ raised — far ahead of the field. Next closest was Kara King at ~$230K (now dropped out and endorsed Gober).
candidates.polling: Polymarket: 85% chance to win nomination. Likely headed to runoff given 10-candidate field.

candidates.name: Jessica Karlsruher
candidates.summary: 5th-generation Texan and conservative lobbyist. Former CEO of the Texas Real Estate Advocacy & Defense (TREAD) Coalition with deep experience in state and federal policy on property rights, water, and economic development.
candidates.background: Born in Kerrville, raised in Houston. BA in Communication Studies from University of Texas at Austin. Began career at the Texas Capitol, then joined the Texas Association of Realtors' government affairs department. Most recently served as CEO of the TREAD Coalition. Experience working on eminent domain reform, private property rights, water infrastructure, and economic development.
keyPositions: Make life affordable again
American energy independence
Make America Healthy Again
Secure the border
Protect private property rights
Fight reckless government spending
pros: Deep Texas policy expertise — property rights, water, economic development
Strong network from years of state Capitol lobbying
5th-generation Texan roots
Endorsed by conservative women's PACs
cons: Lobbyist background may be seen as insider/swamp
Vastly outfunded by Gober
Lower name recognition than top-tier candidates
candidates.fundraising: FEC-registered — significantly behind Gober's $1M+
candidates.polling: Not individually polled — considered a second-tier contender

candidates.name: Rob Altman
candidates.summary: Retired U.S. Army Major with 25+ years of service across multiple combat deployments. Running on a Faith, Family, and Freedom platform. Chair of the Frisco Veterans Advisory Committee.
candidates.background: Joined the U.S. Army at 19 and served 25+ years as both enlisted soldier and commissioned officer, leading teams of 16 to 600 across multiple combat deployments. Retired as Major. Chair of the Frisco Veterans Advisory Committee. Member of the Denton Central Appraisal District (term through 2027). Life member of VFW and American Legion. Member of Sons of the American Revolution.
keyPositions: Veterans' issues and successful transition
National security
Infrastructure investment
Faith-based conservative values
pros: Extensive military service and leadership experience
Active in veteran and community service organizations
Genuine outsider candidate
cons: No political or legislative experience
Minimal fundraising
Low name recognition in a crowded field
candidates.fundraising: Minimal FEC filings
candidates.polling: Polymarket: 9% — distant second to Gober

candidates.name: Scott MacLeod
candidates.summary: Retired U.S. Army Colonel with 31 years of service including Iraq deployment, Hurricane Harvey relief command, and Texas border security operations. Now a tech company CEO. One of the top three media-covered candidates.
candidates.background: BA from Sam Houston State University, graduate of U.S. Army War College. Served 31 years in the U.S. Army, retiring as Colonel. Led Texas National Guard deployment to the Mexico border, commanded Hurricane Harvey relief efforts, deployed to Iraq. After military, became CEO of a tech company developing first responder and hospital training programs.
keyPositions: America First agenda
Prevent illegal immigration
Oppose firearms restrictions
Nationwide voter ID requirements
Congressional term limits
pros: Most military experience of any candidate — 31 years, Colonel rank
Direct border security and disaster relief leadership
Post-military tech CEO experience
cons: Vastly outfunded by Gober
No political experience
Military-heavy resume may not differentiate enough from Altman
candidates.fundraising: FEC-registered — well behind Gober's $1M+
candidates.polling: Considered a top-three candidate by media coverage but no individual polling numbers

candidates.name: Ben Bius
candidates.summary: Huntsville-based real estate developer and independent businessman with deep Texas roots. Built a regional development firm from the ground up.
candidates.background: BA in Finance from Sam Houston State University (1979). Built a real estate investment and development company in Huntsville into a regional firm. Portfolio includes major residential, commercial, and retail developments. Also led B&B Properties, Legacy Builders, Caliber Investment Corporation, and Bius Investments.
keyPositions: Economic development
Job creation
Conservative business values
pros: Successful businessman with tangible community economic impact
Geographically central to the district
Multi-generational Texas roots
cons: No political experience
Low name recognition outside Huntsville area
Minimal campaign infrastructure compared to Gober
candidates.fundraising: FEC-registered — minimal compared to frontrunners
candidates.polling: Not individually polled — lower-tier candidate

candidates.name: Jenny Garcia Sharon
candidates.summary: Houston native and repeat congressional candidate. Previously ran in the 2024 TX-37 Republican primary and lost to Lloyd Doggett in the general. Also ran in TX-35 in 2020 and 2022.
candidates.background: Born in Houston, TX. BA in Administration from University of the Incarnate Word. Has run for Congress multiple times: TX-35 Republican primary (2020, advanced to runoff), TX-37 Republican primary (2022 and 2024). Lost to Rep. Lloyd Doggett in the 2024 general election.
keyPositions: Conservative governance
Border security
pros: Most campaign experience of the lower-tier candidates — multiple runs
cons: Has lost every general election attempt
Prior races were in different districts
Minimal fundraising
candidates.fundraising: Minimal
candidates.polling: Not individually polled — lower-tier candidate

candidates.name: Brandon Hawbaker
candidates.summary: Senior software engineer from Sealy running as a tech-oriented outsider candidate.
candidates.background: BA from DeVry University (2005). Career as a senior software engineer. Based in Sealy, TX.
keyPositions: Technology policy
Government transparency
pros: Tech industry perspective
Outsider status
cons: No political experience
Minimal campaign presence
Low name recognition
candidates.fundraising: Minimal
candidates.polling: Not individually polled — lower-tier candidate

candidates.name: Jeremy Story
candidates.summary: Small business owner and nonprofit director with deep roots in faith-based community organizing. Signed the U.S. Term Limits pledge.
candidates.background: BA in Government from University of Texas. Career includes running several small businesses, serving as an advocacy coordinator and nonprofit director. Affiliated with Campus Renewal, Every Student Sent, America's National Prayer Committee, and the Republican Party of Texas.
keyPositions: Congressional term limits
Federal spending reduction (opposes continuing resolutions)
Vote on budget in small sections for true oversight
Faith-based governance
pros: Small business and nonprofit leadership experience
Specific fiscal policy positions on budget process
Strong faith community network
cons: No political experience
Minimal fundraising
Low name recognition
candidates.fundraising: Minimal
candidates.polling: Polymarket: ~1%

candidates.name: Robert Brown
candidates.summary: Self-described corporate turnaround specialist with 20 years of business experience. Originally from Portland, OR.
candidates.background: Born in Portland, OR. BA from UNLV (2002), graduate degree from University of Phoenix (2004), graduate degree from University of Alaska, Anchorage (2006). 20 years of corporate turnaround experience.
keyPositions: Deregulation
Reduced government spending
pros: Business turnaround experience
cons: Not a native Texan — Oregon roots
No political experience
Minimal campaign presence
candidates.fundraising: Minimal
candidates.polling: Not individually polled — lower-tier candidate

recommendation.reasoning: Trump-endorsed Harvard Law graduate with $1M+ raised, 4x any rival. Endorsed by Trump, Abbott, Cruz, and House Speaker Johnson. Built a major conservative law firm and served as chief lawyer of Musk's America PAC. The overwhelming frontrunner at 85% on prediction markets.
recommendation.strategicNotes: With 10 candidates (down from 11 after Kara King dropped out), a runoff is very likely. The top-three media-covered candidates are Gober, Karlsruher, and MacLeod.
recommendation.caveats: Gober's Musk ties and establishment backing may not appeal to voters seeking a true outsider. Karlsruher offers a strong Texas policy alternative; MacLeod and Altman offer military credentials.

candidates.name: Anthony Gupta
candidates.summary: Founder and CEO of LXMI Capital, an Austin-based real estate firm managing $4B+ in multifamily assets. Stanford-educated engineer and economist running as the sole Republican challenger to long-time incumbent Democrat Donna Howard.
candidates.background: BA in Economics and MS in Civil & Environmental Engineering from Stanford University. Began career in infrastructure construction at Clark Construction and Swinerton Management & Consulting, supporting $2.5B+ in projects. Served at Deloitte Financial Advisory Services. Oversaw real estate and corporate operations at Counsyl, a biotech company acquired by Myriad Genetics for $375M. Became General Partner at Nimes Capital building a private equity portfolio in multifamily, hospitality, and student housing across the Sun Belt. Founded LXMI Capital in Austin, which develops, owns, and operates multifamily real estate in Texas with a focus on repositioning underperforming properties. Also active as an angel investor, advisor, and board member.
keyPositions: Housing and real estate development
Business-friendly economic growth
Property tax reform
Infrastructure investment
pros: Only Republican in the primary — automatic nominee
Deep real estate and business expertise with $4B+ portfolio
Stanford engineering and economics credentials
Brings private-sector operations and construction experience to housing policy
cons: No prior political experience or public office
No visible campaign website, social media presence, or policy platform
District 48 leans heavily Democratic — Donna Howard has held the seat since 2006
No known endorsements or campaign infrastructure
candidates.fundraising: No publicly available campaign finance data found on the Texas Ethics Commission or FEC databases.
candidates.polling: No polling data available. Uncontested Republican primary.

propositions.title: Phase out property taxes
propositions.description: Texas property taxes should be assessed at the purchase price and phased out entirely over the next six years through spending reductions.
propositions.reasoning: Aspirational but popular. Signals strong support for property tax relief.
propositions.background: Texas has no state income tax but relies heavily on property taxes, which totaled $86.8 billion in 2024 — up $23.6 billion since 2018. School districts alone collected $42 billion. Governor Abbott has proposed eliminating school property taxes via constitutional amendment, but replacing that revenue would cost $39.5 billion annually according to the Legislative Budget Board. This proposition goes further, calling for all property taxes to be assessed at purchase price (like California's Prop 13) and then phased out entirely over six years.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, would require replacing $86.8 billion in annual property tax revenue through spending cuts or alternative revenue sources. Critics warn this could necessitate dramatically higher sales taxes or deep cuts to schools, roads, and public services.
supporters: Gov. Greg Abbott (school property tax elimination)
opponents: Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick (supports exemptions, opposes full elimination as unrealistic)
propositions.ifPasses: Signals overwhelming Republican voter support for aggressive property tax elimination. Strengthens Governor Abbott's hand to push school property tax elimination in the 2027 legislative session. Could become a GOP platform plank at the June 2026 convention.
propositions.ifFails: Weakens the case for full property tax elimination. Legislators would likely pursue incremental relief (higher homestead exemptions, lower caps) rather than wholesale phase-out.

propositions.title: Voter approval for local tax hikes
propositions.description: Texas should require any local government budget that raises property taxes to be approved by voters at a November general election.
propositions.reasoning: Direct accountability mechanism for local government spending.
propositions.background: Under current Texas law (SB 2, passed in 2019), local governments cannot increase property tax revenue by more than 3.5% per year without triggering an automatic election. However, increases below that 3.5% threshold are approved by city councils and county commissioners without a public vote. This proposition would require voter approval for any increase at all, shifting power from elected officials to voters at November general elections.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, would add election costs for local governments and could slow revenue growth. Proponents argue it would restrain spending; opponents say it would hamstring local governments' ability to fund services like police, fire, and infrastructure.
propositions.ifPasses: Signals strong voter demand for direct control over local tax increases. Strengthens legislative efforts to tighten the 3.5% revenue cap or require elections for any increase. Could shape 2027 legislation.
propositions.ifFails: Suggests Republican voters are satisfied with the current 3.5% cap and automatic election trigger from SB 2. Reduces pressure for further restrictions on local government taxing authority.

propositions.title: Healthcare & vaccination status
propositions.description: Texas should prohibit denial of healthcare or any medical service based solely on the patient's vaccination status.
propositions.reasoning: Medical freedom issue. Not directly related to most voters' top priorities.
propositions.background: During the COVID-19 pandemic, some healthcare providers required vaccination for certain services or prioritized vaccinated patients. Texas already permits conscientious, religious, and medical exemptions to physician vaccination policies. House Bill 44 was filed in the 88th Legislature to address healthcare discrimination based on vaccination status. The broader medical freedom movement has gained traction in Texas, with multiple bills filed in 2025 to weaken vaccine mandates, coinciding with declining vaccination rates in some communities.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted as law, minimal direct fiscal impact to the state. Could increase healthcare costs if providers must accommodate unvaccinated patients in settings where infection control protocols currently require vaccination.
propositions.ifPasses: Signals Republican voter support for medical freedom legislation. Could lead to bills in the 2027 session prohibiting healthcare providers from denying services based on vaccination status. Becomes a platform priority.
propositions.ifFails: Unlikely to fail among Republican primary voters. A weak showing would suggest the COVID-era medical freedom movement has lost momentum within the GOP base.

propositions.title: Life at fertilization in schools
propositions.description: Texas should require its public schools to teach that life begins at fertilization.
propositions.reasoning: Social conservative priority. Depends on your views on school curriculum.
propositions.background: Following the 2022 overturn of Roe v. Wade, Texas enacted one of the nation's strictest abortion bans. The Texas GOP platform (Plank 117) already urges legislators to require life-affirming fetal development education, including teaching that life begins at fertilization, showing fetal models, live ultrasounds, and educational videos. Only about 19% of Texas schools currently offer sex education, with most emphasizing abstinence-only approaches. This proposition would mandate a specific scientific/philosophical position as curriculum.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, minimal direct cost — primarily curriculum development and teacher training expenses. Could invite costly legal challenges on First Amendment grounds.
opponents: Some medical professionals who note fertilization is one of several scientifically recognized developmental milestones
propositions.ifPasses: Signals strong GOP voter support for incorporating pro-life principles into school curriculum. Could lead to 2027 legislation mandating life-begins-at-fertilization instruction in sex education classes. Reinforces the post-Roe legislative agenda.
propositions.ifFails: Would suggest even Republican primary voters have reservations about mandating this specific curriculum content. Could indicate nuanced views on abortion policy, as polling shows many Texans hold complex positions on the issue.

propositions.title: Ban school health clinics
propositions.description: Texas should ban gender, sexuality, and reproductive clinics and services in K-12 schools.
propositions.reasoning: Social conservative priority. Depends on your views on school health services.
propositions.background: Texas has already enacted several laws restricting gender-related services for minors, including a ban on gender-affirming care for minors (upheld by the Texas Supreme Court) and Senate Bill 12, which bans DEI programs, Gender and Sexuality Alliance clubs, and restricts discussions of gender identity and sexual orientation in K-12 schools. The ACLU has sued over SB 12. This proposition targets any remaining school-based clinics or services related to gender, sexuality, or reproductive health, pushing these services entirely off campus.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, would shift costs for affected services from school districts to families and community health providers. Texas has teen birth rates of 19.4 per 1,000 females aged 15-19, above the national average.
propositions.ifPasses: Signals strong voter support for removing all gender, sexuality, and reproductive health services from public schools. Could lead to 2027 legislation banning school-based health clinics that provide these services, building on existing restrictions in SB 12.
propositions.ifFails: Would suggest GOP voters see value in some school-based health services, or that existing restrictions (SB 12, gender-affirming care ban) are sufficient. Reduces pressure for additional legislation.

propositions.title: Term limits
propositions.description: Texas should enact term limits on all elected officials.
propositions.reasoning: Broadly popular across the political spectrum. Limits entrenchment of career politicians.
propositions.background: The Texas Constitution currently imposes no term limits on state legislators, statewide officeholders, or most elected officials. The governor has no term limit (Abbott is in his third term). The average age of the current Texas Senate is 62.1, with 26 of 31 senators being incumbents. Fifteen states have legislative term limits. The idea polls well across party lines but faces resistance from incumbents who would have to vote to limit their own power. U.S. Term Limits, a national organization, has been pushing for a federal constitutional convention on the issue.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, no direct fiscal impact. Critics argue term limits lead to higher reliance on lobbyists and unelected staff who retain institutional knowledge as legislators cycle out.
supporters: Most Republican and Democratic voters (polls show 70-80% support)
opponents: Some political scientists who argue term limits increase lobbyist influence
propositions.ifPasses: Signals overwhelming voter demand for term limits. Adds pressure on the legislature to pass a constitutional amendment, though incumbents historically resist limiting their own tenure. Could become a litmus-test issue in future primaries.
propositions.ifFails: Extremely unlikely to fail. Term limits consistently poll as one of the most popular reform proposals. A failure here would be a major surprise and would effectively kill the issue for years.

propositions.title: Protect Texas water
propositions.description: Texas should ban the large-scale export, or sale, of our groundwater and surface water to any single private or public entity.
