propositions.reasoning: Water security is a growing Texas concern. Protects a critical resource.
propositions.background: This proposition was driven by businessman Kyle Bass's company (Conservation Equity Management) applying to drill 43 high-capacity wells in East Texas to pump up to 15.9 billion gallons per year from the Carrizo-Wilcox Aquifer — more than triple what the city of Longview uses annually. The plan sparked a rural uprising. State Rep. Cody Harris authored HB 27 during a special session to stop it, and the Texas House passed the bill, but it ultimately failed in the Senate. Texas voters approved $20 billion in water infrastructure bonds in November 2025. At least six other large-scale groundwater pipelines are planned or under consideration.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. If enacted, could limit private water markets but protect rural aquifers from depletion. The San Antonio Water System's similar 48,000 acre-feet extraction from the Carrizo-Wilcox already caused water levels to drop in Lee County, forcing landowners to sink pumps deeper.
supporters: Wayne-Sanderson Farms (filed lawsuit to block Bass permits)
opponents: Some free-market advocates who oppose restricting private water rights
Developers and municipalities seeking new water sources for growing cities
propositions.ifPasses: Strong signal to the legislature to pass water export restrictions in 2027. Strengthens the case for legislation similar to HB 27 that failed in the Senate. Protects rural water sources from large-scale commercial extraction.
propositions.ifFails: Would suggest Republican voters prioritize free-market water rights over rural water protection. Weakens the legislative push to restrict groundwater exports, emboldening large-scale extraction projects.

propositions.title: End services for undocumented immigrants
propositions.description: The Texas Legislature should reduce the burden of illegal immigration on taxpayers by ending public services for illegal immigrants.
propositions.reasoning: Depends on how broadly you define 'public services' and your immigration views.
propositions.background: Federal law already restricts most public benefits for undocumented immigrants. Currently, undocumented immigrants in Texas are eligible for emergency medical treatment, disease immunizations, disaster relief, and K-12 public education (mandated by the 1982 Supreme Court ruling in Plyler v. Doe). Undocumented immigrants pay an estimated $12 billion annually in property taxes nationally and contribute payroll taxes. A federal judge ruled in 2025 that Texas's in-state tuition policy for undocumented students violates federal law. AG Paxton sued Harris County for funding legal defense services for undocumented immigrants. Polling shows 64% of Texans believe there should be a legal pathway for undocumented immigrants.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. The proposition is vague about which services would be cut. Ending emergency healthcare could shift costs to hospitals (federally required to treat emergencies regardless). Ending K-12 education would require overturning Plyler v. Doe, a Supreme Court precedent.
opponents: Texas business groups (who rely on immigrant labor)
propositions.ifPasses: Signals strong GOP voter demand for restricting services to undocumented immigrants. Could push the 2027 legislature to pass bills cutting in-state tuition eligibility, restricting county-funded legal services, or tightening benefits verification. Many proposals would face federal legal challenges.
propositions.ifFails: Unlikely to fail among Republican primary voters. A weak showing would suggest even the GOP base recognizes the complexity of completely ending services, particularly emergency healthcare and K-12 education.

propositions.title: No Democratic committee chairs
propositions.description: The Republican-controlled Texas Legislature should stop awarding leadership positions, including committee chairmanships, to Democrats.
propositions.reasoning: Hyper-partisan. Cross-aisle governance and bipartisan committee work have long Texas traditions.
propositions.background: The Texas House has a long tradition of bipartisan committee leadership. Former Speaker Dade Phelan appointed Democrats to chair 8 of 34 standing committees (down from 13 in the prior session), while keeping Republicans in control of the most powerful committees (spending and taxes). In 2024, 46 incoming Republican House members pledged to only support a speaker who commits to ending Democratic chairmanships. This was a major factor in House leadership dynamics and became one of the Republican Party of Texas's official legislative priorities for 2025. New Speaker Dustin Burrows has continued some bipartisan appointments.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. No direct fiscal impact. Political scientists note that committee composition already heavily favors the majority party, so removing Democratic chairs would have minimal policy impact.
opponents: Former Speaker Dade Phelan (defended the bipartisan tradition)
Political scientists who argue bipartisan committees produce more durable legislation
propositions.ifPasses: Pressures House leadership to end the tradition of bipartisan committee appointments. Could become a litmus test for future speaker races. Signals the GOP base wants fully partisan governance in the legislature.
propositions.ifFails: Vindicates the bipartisan tradition. Signals that Republican primary voters value pragmatic governance over pure partisanship. Reduces pressure on House leadership to strip Democrats of all committee roles.

propositions.title: Prohibit Sharia Law
propositions.reasoning: Foreign religious law has no legal standing in Texas courts already. Purely symbolic.
propositions.background: Sharia law has no legal authority in Texas or any U.S. state — the Constitution's Supremacy Clause, Establishment Clause, and Free Exercise Clause already prevent any religious legal system from superseding civil law. In 2025, Governor Abbott signed HB 4211 banning Sharia-based residential compounds (targeting the proposed EPIC City development). Senator Cornyn introduced the federal 'Defeat Sharia Law in America Act.' A federal appeals court previously blocked Oklahoma's similar ban, finding it likely violated the Establishment Clause by singling out Islam. Baylor philosophy professor Dr. Francis Beckwith called such bans 'unconstitutional' and argued they 'underestimate the ways in which people from diverse religious groups wind up being good Americans.'
propositions.fiscalImpact: Non-binding advisory. No fiscal impact. Legal scholars note that any enacted ban specifically targeting Sharia (rather than all foreign law) would likely face costly constitutional challenges, as occurred in Oklahoma.
supporters: True Texas Project (calls it 'probably the most important' proposition)
opponents: Cato Institute (argues 'no Sharia law is coming to Texas')
Federalist Society scholars (raised Establishment Clause concerns)
propositions.ifPasses: Signals GOP voter support for explicit anti-Sharia legislation. Could lead to a Texas foreign law ban in 2027, though legal scholars warn it would face immediate constitutional challenges if it singles out Islamic law specifically rather than all foreign legal systems.
propositions.ifFails: Would suggest Republican voters view the issue as already addressed by existing constitutional protections and recent legislation (HB 4211). Reduces pressure for additional anti-Sharia legislation.
